headline.main: Themes of Gloom and Doom Fill Japanese Bookstores

lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of bad news in Japan these days yet another recession, continued political fumbling and even mad cow disease. But if books are a window into a society, you would think Japan was on the verge of collapse. ''The Day the Yen Disappears,'' ''2003: Japan's National Bankruptcy'' and ''The Depression of 2002'' are just a few of the alarmist titles tantalizing readers at the corner bookstore. Their shrill tone and easy comparisons to the Weimar Republic and soup kitchens of the 1930's suggest that the end is near for the world's second-largest economy. Or does it?
abstract: Article discusses high number of books in Japanese bookstores that deal with demise of Japan's economic structure as it is now known; several examples cited; photo; graph (M)
